If the arrow is fixed in the head bone and has already penetrated into one of the cerebral cavities, and there appears some manifestation of those conditions that I mentioned: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, instead remove it until equilibrium comes to be after a day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow has reached the sifach [a part of the body], then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except within the body bone and does not penetrate up to the sifach: and he remains sick for a few days, and nothing happens to him from those incidents; then use your skills in drawing out and extracting the arrow.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If it is fixed strongly and does not yield to your attempt at drawing [the arrow]: then administer trepanning around the area of the arrow, as I have instructed you: afterwards attend to the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow is already hidden inside the body location and concealed from perception: then seek it out with your attempts.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you sense it, then draw her in with certain tools that suit its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot manage over it due to constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow deeply inside, and there is no opening, nor nerve, nor vein there: then wait upon it until the wound expands and becomes possible for extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If it is held by ears to which there are attachments, then release the fixed flesh around them from every side using all methods that you can. Use tools if they cannot be applied due to inability to manipulate the tissue in breaks of the ears and twisting of them until it resolves.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you perform the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is located, then use the twisting motion of your hand with forceps to all parts until you make it come out: and apply delicate finesse so that the arrow is not broken, and that it becomes difficult for you to pull it, and also its removal.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot remove it at once, then allow it for several days until the surrounding tissues decompose.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then remove it again. Indeed, the arrow should be extracted. But if the blood flow is against you, then administer what we said about treatment in its chapter: and guard your strength from cutting a vein, or a nerve, or a tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And use every skillful method possible for the extraction of the arrow: and let it be with ease, tranquility, or perhaps slowly but firmly, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And you must make the patient sick according to the figure when you pull out the arrow, as it was with the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however, it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that emerges from the opposite side of the body, or has already begun to reach towards the exterior, or causes a lump at the tip of the arrow through sensation from the nearby upper part of the skin, making it visible. Therefore cut it above it and make the cut according to how many forceps can take in her.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it (the arrow): for it becomes easy for exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness until the arrow presses into the bone and widens itself. Then pull it (the arrow).
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: dismiss it for a few days; then reapply it until it escapes.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	And if the arrowwood is in it, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	And if the wood fell and there is a need to apply force: then insert that tool into it, so that its concavity enters into the arrow's tail: then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	And if the Arrow is concave, then push it out with the tool inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	Indeed, an arrow moves through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	And if the arrow is poisoned, then you must hollow out all the flesh where the poison is: if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	And then care for it with what is suitable in relation to this.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	And if the arrow has fallen in the chest, or in the abdomen, or in the bladder, or on the side: and it is close to what you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut it, and dig away from the incision of a vein or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	And afterwards heal the wound if you see it, and care for it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of Forcips, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Their ends are similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp over an arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many types are made from them, large, small and medium, according to the size of the arrow and its shape, and the width of the wound and its conformation.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Shape of the Impeller concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape of the impeller for the deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is like the extremity of the deaf person, such as the radius, so that its entry is directed into a concave bow and it is pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This is the concave end of the impeller, like a feather of a bird: so that the entry point of the arrow is directed into it and its impulse is applied.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On venous bloodletting.
Caput XCVII.	Title 77.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins for bloodletting, which run their course in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Among these, sixteen are found in the head: two of the pulse veins, which are behind the ears and called 'two herbs'; and two arteries, which appear in both temples; and two veins that are in the two tear ducts of both eyes, which are called 'watching veins'; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two jugulars, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins to be used for bloodletting in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic, and it comes from the side of the sleeve: and they call this vein the head vein commonly.
Et Fusca.	And Fuchsia.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is called Media Una, and it is composed from the branch of Basilica and the branch of Cephalica: and they name her common blood of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And Basilica, it is placed inside the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And they call her by the common name of abdominal blood.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the vein of the arm, it is placed over the elbow: that is where phlebotomy occurs, and that is which appears above the thumb clearly.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Salvatella: it is the vein that exists between the annular and the minimal [artery]: and there are two branches for her.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the calf, and in the foot, there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the wild side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is Saphena: its location is at the heel on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And vein Nesse: its location is at the heel on the wild side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the calf, there are three other veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	¶ On bloodletting with two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	For bloodletting with two veins which are after the ears, it is beneficial for old catarrhs, and headache, and ear discharge, and bad head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting is as I describe it.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is done by cutting the head of the sick person: and its scalp is rubbed at the site of the two veins with good friction using a coarse cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the patient stretch his neck with the arm, until two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And those places are behind the ears at two depressed spots on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So, search for these with your finger, and where you feel the pulse under your finger, there mark the spots with a branding iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a surgical scalpel for phlebotomy, and that one is called the Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin until the phlebotomy tool reaches the mouth of the vein.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin towards above, and cut the vein along with the skin in a descending manner.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the cut be as much as two joined fingers, or roughly that; and make it bleed as much as you can.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with bandages, and remove them when the wound has healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now, at the beginning of this book, there is mention of making cuts and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Section 1: On bloodletting using two arteries in the arm.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	However, two arteries which are useful in the two places of bloodletting for benefit: it is the temporal artery and the superficial temporal artery, and the flow of excess secretions towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting for these is as I am going to tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient should stretch their neck significantly until two veins become visibly apparent: and it must be demonstrated that the pulse of these is felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark the spots with a branding iron.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein with your finger up to the upper part, and insert the phlebotomus coming downwards below it, then lift the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did in the other two veins: and let blood flow from the blood according to the amount needed.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then relieve the constriction of the patient, and place your finger on the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place a cloth and strips over it, and bind the area strongly above the constriction: and remove it until the patient is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now recall that preparation, and its incision, and the extraction at the beginning of this book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	¶ Concerning frontal vein bloodletting after cephalic bloodletting.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	However, the benefit of frontal vein bloodletting is after cephalic bloodletting, for old ailments of the face: and for migraine, and redness: and for foul sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this bloodletting is as I will tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	Grip the patient's neck with your hand until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the tool that is called the Fossorial Instrument.
Cuius haec est forma.	And this is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent edge of the Fossorial Instrument's head over the vein and strike it with your thumbnail or with another tool in a similar manner. Allow the blood to flow according to how you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then relieve the puncture of the patient and bind it until they are healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes an opening is made with a broad bloodletting instrument.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that it be a phlebotomy for acute extremities, like the other phlebotomies, indeed it should be for broad extremities.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And for the phlebotomy, follow the deviation: because it is close by: and perhaps when the phlebotomy tool is fine, it might break within it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	¶ On Phlebotomy in two Lacrymal veins.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment for the two veins that are located in the two lacrimal areas of both eyes is aimed at relieving symptoms caused by scabies and redness: and also the disturbances within the eye and the discomforts on the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of these phlebotomies is such that the sick person should tighten their neck with an outstretched hand.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then perform the phlebotomy on them, and stand above his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And perform the phlebotomy according to the deviation to a length that is somewhat short, using a small phlebotomy tool, slightly broadened because there is no flesh in the location.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	Indeed, if the phlebotomy tool is thin for an extremity, perhaps it might break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make the bleeding run out as much as you need from the blood that is there.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place your thumbs over them and tighten them at night once, then release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	¶ On Phlebotomy of the Nasal Veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the Nasal Veins is performed for acute fevers and violent heat, as well as facial discomforts such as headaches and redness that occur on the face: particularly when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And what is the quality of this bloodletting, that it tightens the patient's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a delicate, long bloodletting tool. Fix it in the middle of the rabbit's body, between what distinguishes the nose according to its right orientation.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein is not perceptible by touch there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it must be that your hand with the bloodletting tool is only slightly pressed: and you should make the flow from the blood according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie that one overnight.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	### Guidelines for Venous Bloodletting
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Two forms of bloodletting with Guidegi are useful for constriction of breathing, and the onset of leprosy, and melancholic illnesses, and pustular eruptions and bad sores, and those that corrode, that is, herpes-like conditions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of these bloodlettings is such that they tighten the patient under both on their neck when bound: and let the artisan stand over the patient's head, and the patient should sit on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then direct the bloodletting tool along the vein to the width of the bloodletting, slightly pressing it.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood a measured amount, or according to what you see as needed for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do similarly with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then release the bandage, and tie both veins together in the middle: so that the patient does not get overheated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her rest until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	Indeed, the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On bloodletting using a syringe by Alhuberish.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	However, Algeberich considers bloodletting with a syringe to be beneficial: because it facilitates the absorption of alcohol and the decay of gum tissue: and bad sores: and cracks in the lips, and bad sores, even those that are in the nose, and around its circumference.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of such bloodletting is to make the patient sit in front of you and hold their neck with your arm.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn the patient's lips and look at two veins: one is from the right lip, and the other is from their left side: and the demonstration of each is by the darkening (or discoloration) of the armpit.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because there are small, dark veins around them.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So make each cut in the direction of incidence.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt about you, and you do not know which one it is: then direct yourself to the cut of the larger ones, and that one will be more obvious.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly, do the same for the two veins in the upper lip: and there is quite a lot of custom with that: and make cuts for the two veins in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On bloodletting using the vein under the tongue after the cephalic bloodletting procedure.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Indeed, the two veins which are under the tongue for bloodletting are useful: because the cephalic bloodletting is aimed at ulcers in the throat, nausea of the stomach, and discomforts of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting is this, that the sick person should sit between your hands in front of the sun: and observe his breath, and look under his tongue from the side of him one vein, and from the other side of him another vein: and each color descends to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore both for bloodletting: and guard yourself not to make the last your hands in the act of bloodletting.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For beneath him are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	¶ Concerning the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	And indeed there are three veins that undergo bloodletting at the elbow, which in all people have a custom of flowing during bloodletting.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bloodletting is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with a myrtle broad lancet: or by rubbing with oil for thinness of the descent: or by cutting with a surgical knife and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them there are types that are broad and fine according to the width and tightness of the veins. The form of the myrtle lancet for bloodletting is such that it is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening shallow, full, advancing, visible, large veins, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is smaller in width and more slender at the tip.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bloodletting of thin veins that contain thin yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On Bloodletting in the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica, which is one of these three types of bloodletting, proves to be beneficial.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it extracts blood from the illnesses that are under the throat and neck, as it follows the chest and belly; and suits a bloodletting method for a blooddrawer, so they should be careful and avoid fear of it because there is an artery beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	So if they go wrong and add to the point of bloodletting, it will hit that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary that the blooddrawer use the Basilica with a prickling bloodletting tool: rather, she should use one that follows with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	And if the appearance of the Basilica is not evident with a clear manifestation, then it should be replaced by another one and switched to another, or you should search for one of its branches. Or use the bloodletting tool called 'Funus Brachii' instead of that.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is indeed evident and can be used along with the bloodletting tool Anesil, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you use bloodletting of its own kind, then it is necessary to prepare before tightening the arm bandage until you can touch the site until you know the pulse location.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the site with hot wax, then place the arm, and cut the vein section in a concave manner using Alnesil's bloodletting tool, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful not to strike the impact through the space from the site of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, with the tightening of the bandage, an increase at the site marked with wax, then that increase is the expansion of the artery: so she should do it properly.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you observe blood flowing during phlebotomy in a manner similar to a child's urine, and the blood is fine, red, then you will know that it comes from arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	So then hurry up, and place your finger on it at the longer distance, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	So when blood is taken out (as it is taken multiple times), then grip the arm, and let it go: and beware of the patient's movement due to fear: and be over him/her.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move him for a few days until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood is not being taken and it's overpowering you: and there isn't any medicine available to you at the moment, then cut the artery when you see it.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	Because its extremities contract and blood is taken out.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of leather thong and make it into two. Take one half and hold it tightly over the spot where the vein is tightened up, with the bandage and small stones until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is taken out, that's good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of it with the person whose memory has returned from the place where small stones were removed and blood flowed. And stopping blood in many positions isn't difficult due to the lack of wounds and possibility of bandaging from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	¶ Concerning phlebotomy for the vein Fossa.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The vein Fossa is useful for phlebotomy as it carries blood from the upper part of the head and lower parts of the body. This is because it is composed of a branch of the basilic vein and a branch of the cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is necessary for the bloodletter that she be above his fear of bloodletting, because there is a nerve under her.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore they add to the puncture for bloodletting, and he finds a nerve, it happens to her that she becomes unconscious, and healing becomes difficult for him, and perhaps she may not be completely healed.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is often perceived by touch.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	And in some people if it is hidden and subtle, not being shown: then you should use the bloodletting method that you know where to apply it, with a section like Alnesil's, and accurately find the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	And if there is a vein between two nerves, then find the vein by its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	¶ On the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	As for bloodletting of the Cephalic Vein, it is helpful because it draws blood from the head and relieves eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary to apply bloodletting specifically to this vein, if you wish, using an oily bloodletting tool or a myrrh bloodletting tool: for it is the healthiest of all veins because there is no artery nor nerve underneath.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, when performing bloodletting, it is advisable to apply the tool gently on top of the head only and search for a softer spot: it does not harm her if it is not found immediately with one strike, so that you can apply the bloodletting tool to that area several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, it may happen in some people that an abscess forms when bloodletting is not done with the first strike, but this apophasis does not harm her in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the utility of phlebotomy and precautions in practicing it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its incidents, originate from the correction that one must consider in it.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, you must understand for what it is necessary that you know, namely that phlebotomy should not be administered except as part of maintaining health and persistence in its upkeep, and vigilance against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that phlebotomy is done using three veins which are found on the arm, namely the Cephalic, and the Dark, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that phlebotomy is performed at the beginning of April on an empty stomach, truly, and during summer: and autumn, and winter after congestion when signs of fullness are evident.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And phlebotomy is performed on the first or third day, after three hours have passed from that day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, phlebotomy which is administered during illnesses does not have a predetermined hour. Rather, when occasion and necessity call for it, it can be performed at night, day, or any hour, at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary to perform phlebotomy on children until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor is pregnancy during menstruation. However, it can be performed from the fourth to the seventh month of pregnancy.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And old men are not subjected to phlebotomy unless they have already passed sixty years of age.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for any manner, it is necessary that they cleanse their intestines before the phlebotomy with a mild enema if there is a large amount of retained feces in them. This way, to prevent potentially harmful, putrid excesses from intestines attracting to the main limbs during phlebotomy.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	The patient is not bled with the pincers, that is, the nausea-inducing emetics: nor is he vomited at or made drunk until this is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	The sick man does not have hydrocele.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let bloodletting be avoided after a bout of colic, vomiting, abdominal pain, increased sexual activity, labor, exercise, watchkeeping, fasting, and anything else that dissipates virtue from bodily or animal strength.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Next, in the subtlety of fluids before this, if blood is thick with food and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Next, if bathing doesn't forbid anything, the patient should bathe or engage in some exercise to refine the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And apply bloodletting to his chest on the third day, as we said: and try so that his body is cleansed of all animal evils that might occur that day: such as distress, anger, fear, and similarly, all physical events like labor, punishment, overconsumption, and similar issues.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let his seat be filled with the things of which human use flows by custom from their aromaticity, smell, flavor and similar qualities through the possibility of quantity.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Next, the bloodletting physician should sit on a stool that is higher than the height required for bloodletting. Afterward, he extends his arm and rubs it with his own hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Next, tie the ligature with a thong, and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, for when an unequal or excessive constriction occurs in the constriction, it then prohibits the flow of blood. Or if there is a weakening of the constriction, even that prohibits the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then, after the ligation, it should be that the one to perform the bloodletting rubs their hands together until the veins are filled and are perceptible to sensation.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then, the bloodletter should cleanse the area with some old oil, in the proper manner.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then, place his index finger of his left hand on the vein at the desired location for the bloodletting, a little bit: so that it does not escape the vein, and percussion is set.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For, within veins is what you find like a fleeing chord at bloodletting: and from them it is that which is full of windiness: and when the one to perform bloodletting places their hands on such, it contracts under the bloodletting, and it is diverted by the bloodletter, and the bloodletter does not open the vein: and if they do open it, it becomes constricted. Therefore, for this reason it should be that the bloodletter holds firmly, and is diligent in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then, place down the one to perform bloodletting.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein is opened from the elbow region, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeatedly do this at another place below that region or above it with pressure: if the location does not allow.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it does not allow, or if the patient expands, then let him go for one day, or two days: and do not tighten the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it might attract a warm pustule.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should they enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he may repeat the bloodletting, if desired.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small or if the blood flows subtly: and you measure to ensure that no quantity of it escapes from the blood: then repeatedly perform bloodletting at the hole itself according to its direction, and add a little in each operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with urgency before the site is sown, for the wound is usually small in many people during surgery.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	And if you see it already sown up, then do not proceed over it completely, for there is nothing to excuse before you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put on top of it something from the fat and oil mixture, because it expedites the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	This method is better here than the actual oil itself, and than other types of oil as well.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the oil mixture in all of your bloodlettings, where blood flows out when you puncture veins under prohibition for blood flow. And they do this with a preparation from Tyrian purple and saffron, when it is placed over the spot from one of them.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood thickens and breaks up when it is coarse.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If there happens to be a large wound during bloodletting, which often occurs, especially for those who are not bled except through that method or have small openings in veins, then proceed and place on the spot a sponge soaked in water and salt, gently heated: and bind it once: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do that after the blood has flowed out of the same vein or another vein until its full amount is out.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If there remains in the place for some days a residue of blackness or verdure after bloodletting, it is not harmful. And if you wish, apply something from myrrh or balsam: or something from the mint juice, that is calamus or similar to that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	Indeed, quite often it happens that there are pustules and prominences during bloodletting in the Basilica style.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand on it, then if you find softness upon pressing it onto itself, then that prominence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, take care, as you place upon her (or him) something from what we said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster with it where there is hardness, so that the place may harden.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it along with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And you must take out from every person in their blood according to the strength of its qualities.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what becomes apparent from the color that reddens over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it go until it turns red; and similarly if you see that it is thick: then let it go until it becomes finer; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the one who is full, strong, and requires blood extraction by means of a single method, so that bloodletting may be increased through the veins, and become transverse: and in the one who is weak, it should be opposite to this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extracts it in various ways, and that there be a tight hole. And better than what is administered in bloodletting through veins is for it to be a crosscut section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from bleeding and from cutting the nerve. And it is better and more advantageous than bloodletting along its width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those who are accustomed to come through bloodletting with scorching (syncopis), it is necessary that before the bloodletting they eat a moderate piece of bread soaked in water with pomegranate juice: or secaniabin if it has been heated. And extract him from his blood in three ways, or four times.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the blood is cooled in nature, then before a bloodletting he should take bread infused in mule's milk syrup, or in a syrup sweetened with honey, seasoned with spices, or in an aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if there occurs syncope at bloodletting and the cause of his bleeding is many: then it must be that he drinks meat broth, and a subtle aromatic syrup; and uses aromatics with algae and linseeds for rubbing on his chest with this: and makes use of other things which we said in division in chapter syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	And for those who wish to empty their arm and release their blood again: it must be that he who has bloodletting because of excessive evacuation, and his strength is weak, allows his blood to be released gradually through the amount of strength over consecutive days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	And those who wish to empty their arm and release their blood again, if their body is strong: then do this after seven hours, or nine from their first bloodletting.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	And those who wish to draw blood from their body against the side towards which it inclines: it must happen to them on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	And in whose body there is already much blood that has been heated and is increasing, causing a fever to occur: it must be that the blood leaves him once through the mouth, and large quantities are extracted from him. And extend the opening until syncope occurs. After you have maintained all conditions of bloodletting, and place your hand on his pulse at the course of the blood so that death does not occur instead of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Indeed, it often happens like this when the bloodletter doesn't know and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you are trying to relieve the arm and then relieve the blood flow in a second stage, when the vein's opening has already been sealed off, and makes the removal of blood difficult, to press upon it with pressure while in shock, and let the clamp be extended quickly either way.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	And that is a great evil, indeed dismiss it, until the second bloodletting occurs.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the sharpness of a bloodletting tool that which has coagulated from the blood at the opening of the vein, and place something dissolved in water over it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something from tarragon oil or saffron over it, and put it under gentle compression until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed there is already an abscess in the vein, then release it, and do not hold it until the abscess subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	But if necessity prompts to relieve blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either use the bloodletting tool over that place, or in the arm at another vein elsewhere.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But for the bloodletting of the arm's vein at the location of Fossa and Basilica, when they are not found and are hidden, because it is made up from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this bloodletting is such that the sick person should immerse their hand in warm water until it turns red and the vein becomes clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then, when the procedure is carried out, apply pressure with a band not too tight but of moderate size.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then, the bloodletting tool should be used gradually across (the area), not laterally, nor in the direction of length; and make the opening wide, and have your bloodletting operation so that you apply bloodletting slightly over the stitch on the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is prevented that blood's outlet, then repeatedly immerse your hand in warm water, and let the blood flow in the water until you achieve what you need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If however you find yourself in days of summer, then omit the repetition of your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And it is indeed placed that the flow of blood in water is numerous during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And this method of bloodletting is beneficial to all veins since there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of Saluatella uses the right hand and relieves ailments in the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this method of phlebotomy is to grip the mahason hand with a ligament or with your own hand after you insert it into warm water until the vein inflates and its presence becomes very evident.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then perform bloodletting by crossing over the (affected) area.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you hit it completely, that will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve, do not withdraw your hand with the bloodletting instrument.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Underneath it, there are exposed nerves from the flesh of the fingers.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeatedly put your hand into warm water and let the blood flow in that.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in warm water, the blood will clot in the vein's opening and prevent its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	So when you have extracted the amount necessary from the blood, then place oil and salt over the vein: so that it does not harden quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly you should do with every tightly bound branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The reduction of the blood of his phlebotomy however from his left hand, is: because it is conveying to the spleen's discomforts: and similarly perform the phlebotomy of him, as you performed in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The reduction of the blood of his phlebotomy related to the veins, is for the discomforts which are in the lower part of the body, such as the discomforts of the uterus, and retention of menstrual flow, and malfunctions of the kidneys, and old sores on the thighs and legs, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of his bloodletting is that the ill man should immerse his foot in hot water: and he should perform a rubbing over it until the veins are abundant: and tie above the cut on the foot with lint.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	Indeed, the site of the veins is at the heel, facing the big toe: and they branch out from it into the face of the foot many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, bloodletting should be performed in the larger branch of it, or at the heel in its aggregation: because this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If bloodletting were performed on the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And suppose your bloodletting in which you perform the bloodletting from obliquely, as if you are trying to hit it: and let the bloodletting be called Neshil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If however the flow of blood is obstructed, then immerse his foot in warm water: and let the blood flow into that, until it is discharged.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the bloodletter misses the vein in the first attempt, then he should proceed with the bloodletting to the upper part little by little, for there is safety, and you do not expect evil from it when you avoid the nerves as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly when the Saphenous vein of the other foot is equal.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel from the inside of the leg.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The effectiveness of bloodletting in such cases is when there is pain in the heel, which occurs due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	The quality of bloodletting in this case is to allow the sick person to enter into a bath and warm it up gradually. Then draw on his leg from the side of the heel up to above the ankle by four fingers, using a long thin needle; for it can only be seen because of that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears then according to any ability you can do it, or according to the reflux: it is better either if you make an incision at that point or cut through it.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	Its location is helpful, and this vein is very hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the touch, then use bloodletting on one of its branches. The one that appears is on the back of the foot and towards the ear region. Be careful around nerves and make the bleeding from the blood as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then release the constriction and place leather over the site of bloodletting, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	Indeed, it heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ On the operation of the wind and its quality for use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 48.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Winds occur from the horns and from air, and from wind.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And indeed, Wind Action happens in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One method involves scarification and the extraction of blood: and there is wind action without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	This 'V通风' which is without incision, operates in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	And indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the types of ventilation that involve incision and bloodletting occur at fourteen places on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	There are fourteen places on the body to which these types of ventilation can be applied: One is Ventosatio Alnocrati, which is at the very back of the head; one is Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck; there are two Alhagdahim ventilations, each corresponding to a pair of cervical laminae simultaneously; one is Vientosae menti, located under the jawbone near the lower part of the mouth; there are two shoulder blade ventilations; one is Vientosae Alachosos at the end of the tail; there are two lung ventitations, each situated in the middle of both arms; there are two leg ventilations; and finally, there are two kidney ventilations.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed, the process of ventilation does not draw out a little blood from minute punctures in your flesh. Because of this, its power does not escape from them as happens with bloodletting.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary that ventilation, either with fire or without it, be administered when conditions arise due to fullness (diseases), until the entire body has been cleansed.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity prompts us to apply ventilation due to illness or by custom, we administer it at all times during the beginning of the month, at its end, and in its middle, as well as at any other time that occurs.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because there are people who when the blood increases within them until it needs to be drained through ventilation, they find a heaviness and dizziness in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there are those who find fullness and redness on their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there are those who find itching on their face and forehead, as well as darkness and confusion in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there are those who tremble at the place of their windpipe.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there are those who find the taste of blood in their mouth: or they may be troubled with their tongue and it might be that blood is expelled.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see blood and redness, slain people and wounds, and things similar to these in their sleep.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	So when we see something from them, and particularly if it occurs on the third day of the month: we then predict that the windpipe will start to function again after passing through two or three hours.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The discomfort of the windpipe at the back of the neck is as follows: it tends to increase in the head and what flows out reaches the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should occur after a full body evacuation.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed the cephalic phlebotomy that produces a suction.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use this practice on someone with a cold complexion or where there is phlegm.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes great harm to such individuals.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this, it is not allowed to use these practices on old individuals or those who have cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	And if one applies this practice excessively, forgetfulness arises over it.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for that reason it is necessary to instruct the Ventosator, so he withdraws his hand with the windbag somewhat below the area of operation, fearing the risk of forgetting the origin.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alkehel is at the site of the Phlebotomy of Fuscae and the Phlebotomy of Basilica. And for this reason it combines with dyspnea, constriction of breathing, suction sound of the instrument, coughing, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to move the Alkehel suction pump somewhat upwards because if placed below, it causes weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio or Alhagdahim combines with head injuries, ophthalmia, and migraines, as well as puncturing, toothache, and is at the site of the Phlebotomy of Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to instruct the Ventosator not to press his hand with the scarification: so as not to damage an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosation at the chin combines with saliva in the mouth, and gum decay, and similar conditions that occur in the mouth: it serves as a place for phlebotomy called alieherich which is situated on both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosation of the spatulas combines with alchafacham, which is produced from folding and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosation of the inner parts of two fingers combines with benefit of phlebotomies of three veins - Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalica: for it draws blood from all those fine veins which are in the flesh. And these smaller veins draw out from other thicker veins until the attraction reaches the three larger veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you should instruct the Windistributor that he must not proceed too far during incisions: because there is flesh stripped off, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The suction device that is used to draw out the air, when applied over hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers, leads to bleeding.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should instruct the Windistributor to ensure that the suction device is large and made of air. For it needs a strong suction and perhaps the finer suction devices may break, requiring larger incisions during the process.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The limb suction devices reduce the evident diminution; for they draw blood from the entire body and bring old pains to the kidneys, uterus, and bladder. They induce menstruation, cause cramps, and result in fatigue: standing as alternatives to double phlebotomy and other forms of treatment.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they greatly weaken the body and cause syncope to occur in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the improvement of the Alhorcobe's suction is similar to that of improving two limb suction treatments.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of positioning the Windistributors is such that you place the suction device in the first void and use a balanced suction. Do not prolong the position of the windistributor, but put them quickly and remove them quickly, so that fluids arrive at the location evenly: do not stop repeating this until you see the area already red and inflamed, and blood rash appears: then, perform incisions, and repeat the suction gradually over time.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those who have tender flesh and few hairs, you should perform one incision only on them, no more: so as not to cause the area to become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the wind instrument user, that he should increase the incision and depth somewhat less: and moderate the suction with ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is congestion in the blood, then you must incise it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In vinegar, first an opening is made for the subtle clarification of blood and its moisture; and in the second, a detailed investigation for the meticulous extraction of thickened blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is extremely fleshy, then a third vinegar incision should be made: in order to achieve the final outcome.
